facts.text: This is a Civil Appeal No. 170 of 1956 by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 12, 1955 of the Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 170 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 12th January, 1955, of the Calcutta High Court in exercise of its Special Jurisdiction under the Chartered Accountants Act, 1949, in Matter No. 107 of 1954.

facts.text: The material facts leading to the present appeal are not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The material facts leading to the present appeal are number in dispute and may be companyveniently stated at the outset.

facts.text: On July 17, 1933, the respondent was enrolled as a registered accountant under the Auditors Certificate Rules, 1932.

anchor.surface_text: On July 17, 1933, the respondent was enrolled as a registered accountant under the Auditors Certificate Rules, 1932. When the Chartered Accountants Act, 1949, came into, operation, the respondents name was entered as a Member of the Institute of Chartered Accountants of lndia on July 1, 1949.

facts.text: Respondent's name was entered as a Member of the Institute of Chartered Accountants of India on July 1, 1949 when the Chartered Accountants Act, 1949 came into operation.

anchor.surface_text: When the Chartered Accountants Act, 1949, came into, operation, the respondents name was entered as a Member of the Institute of Chartered Accountants of lndia on July 1, 1949. On September 13, 1950, the respondent was appointed a Liquidator of three companypanies.

facts.text: On September 13, 1950, the respondent was appointed a Liquidator of three companies.

anchor.surface_text: On September 13, 1950, the respondent was appointed a Liquidator of three companypanies. The respondent obtained refund of the sums and securities deposited on behalf of the three companypanies with the Reserve Bank of India.

facts.text: The respondent obtained refund of the sums and securities deposited on behalf of the three companies with the Reserve Bank of India.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent obtained refund of the sums and securities deposited on behalf of the three companypanies with the Reserve Bank of India. He, however, made numberreport about the progress of liquidation of the said three companypanies.

facts.text: The respondent made no report about the progress of liquidation of the three companies.

anchor.surface_text: He, however, made numberreport about the progress of liquidation of the said three companypanies. Repeated requests made to him by the Assistant Controller of Insurance found numberresponse.

facts.text: Repeated requests made to the respondent by the Assistant Controller of Insurance found no response.

anchor.surface_text: Repeated requests made to him by the Assistant Controller of Insurance found numberresponse. As Liquidator the respondent gave a cheque to Shri S. K. Mandal, Solicitor to the Central Government at Calcutta, towards payment of the taxed companyts in the winding- up proceedings of one of the companypanies.

facts.text: As Liquidator, the respondent gave a cheque to Shri S. K. Mandal, Solicitor to the Central Government at Calcutta, towards payment of the taxed costs in the winding-up proceedings of one of the companies; the cheque was returned dishonoured.

anchor.surface_text: As Liquidator the respondent gave a cheque to Shri S. K. Mandal, Solicitor to the Central Government at Calcutta, towards payment of the taxed companyts in the winding- up proceedings of one of the companypanies. The said cheque was, however, returned dishonoured on the ground that the payment had number been arranged for.

facts.text: The Assistant Controller of Insurance cancelled the appointment of the respondent as Liquidator by letter dated October 29, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: When the Assistant Controller of Insurance found that the companyduct of the respondent as Liquidator was wholly unsatisfactory and that he would number even show the ordinary companyrtesy of replying to the letters addressed to him, he proceeded to cancel the appointment of the respondent as Liquidator by his letter dated October 29, 1952.

facts.text: The respondent was called upon to hand over all books of account, records, documents etc. to Shri N. N. Das, who was appointed Liquidator in his place.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was then called upon to hand over all books of account, records, documents, etc., to Shri N. N. Das, who was appointed a Liquidator in his place.

facts.text: Shri Das and the Assistant Controller of Insurance made repeated demands on the respondent to deliver assets and records of the three companies to Shri Das.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Das as well as the Assistant Controller of Insurance then made repeated demands on the respondent to deliver to Shri Das the assets and records of the three companypanies.

facts.text: It is common ground that the respondent had securities of the value of Rs. 11,950 and cash sum of Rs. 642 on account of United Common Provident Insurance Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the respondent had with him securities of the value of Rs. 11,950 and a cash sum of Rs. 642 on account of the United Common Provident Insurance Co. Ltd.

facts.text: The respondent had securities to the value of Rs. 12,100 on account of Asiatic Provident Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: He had also with him securities to the value of Rs. 12,100 on account of the -Asiatic Provident Co. Ltd., and securities and cash on account of the Citizens of India Provident Insurance Co. Ltd.

facts.text: The respondent had securities and cash on account of Citizens of India Provident Insurance Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: He had also with him securities to the value of Rs. 12,100 on account of the -Asiatic Provident Co. Ltd., and securities and cash on account of the Citizens of India Provident Insurance Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Out of these amounts, the respondent returned only securities of face value Rs. 10,000 and Rs. 350 of Asiatic Provident Co. Ltd. and United Common Provident Insurance Co. Ltd. respectively.

anchor.surface_text: Out of these amounts the respondent returned only securities of the face value of Rs. 10,000 and Rs. 350 of Asiatic Provident Co. Ltd., and United Common Provident Insurance Co. Ltd., respectively.

facts.text: The respondent failed to send any further securities or cash held by him on account of the three companies.

anchor.surface_text: He failed to send any further securities or cash held by him on account of the said three companypanies. It was at this stage that a companyplaint was lodged against the respondent with the Council of the Institute of Chartered Accountants of India in Calcutta.

facts.text: A complaint was lodged against the respondent with the Council of the Institute of Chartered Accountants of India in Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: It was at this stage that a companyplaint was lodged against the respondent with the Council of the Institute of Chartered Accountants of India in Calcutta.

facts.text: The disciplinary committee of the Council inquired into the matter as required by the Act.

anchor.surface_text: As required by the provisions of the Act, the disciplinary companymittee of the Council inquired into the matter.

facts.text: Notice was served on the respondent but he filed no written statements within the time fixed.

anchor.surface_text: Notice was served on the respondent but he filed numberwritten statements within the time fixed.

facts.text: On August 1, 1953, a letter was received from the respondent that he was ill and unable to attend personally and requested adjournment.

anchor.surface_text: On August 1, 1953, a letter was received from the respondent that he was ill and was unable to attend personally. The respondent had also requested for the adjournment of the case.

facts.text: Proceedings adjourned to August 29, 1953, on which date the respondent was represented by counsel who filed respondent's affidavit stating prepared to hand over cash, books etc. without rendering accounts.

anchor.surface_text: Proceedings were accordingly adjourned to August 29, 1953, on which date the respondent was represented by a companynsel who filed the respondents affidavit stating that he was prepared to hand over the entire cash, books of account, etc., to the newly appointed Liquidator without rendering the necessary accounts.

facts.text: Shri Das gave evidence before the disciplinary committee.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that Shri Das, the subsequently appointed Liquidator, gave evidence before the disciplinary companymittee.

facts.text: The respondent failed to appear or take part in the proceedings despite opportunities.

anchor.surface_text: Though several opportunities were given to the respondent to appear before the disciplinary companymittee he failed to appear or to take part in the proceedings.

facts.text: The committee made its report on September 13, 1953 finding respondent guilty of gross negligence in conduct of professional duty in not handing over charge.

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately the companymittee made its report on September 13, 1953, and found that the respondent was guilty of gross negligence in the companyduct of his professional duty in number handing over charge of the assets and the books of account of the said companypanies to the newly appointed Liquidator.

facts.text: The Council agreed with the finding in substance but viewed acts and omissions as more serious than gross negligence.

anchor.surface_text: This report was companysidered by the Council itself as required by the Act. Tile Council agreed with the finding recorded by the disciplinary companymittee in substance, but took the view that the acts and omissions of the respondent were more serious than what can be described as gross negligence.

facts.text: The Council's finding was forwarded to the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta under section 21(1) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The finding of the Council was then forwarded to the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta as required by section 21  1  of the Act and the matter was heard by the learned Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Lahiri.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court by judgment of Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Lahiri dated January 12, 1955 rejected the reference on ground no action could be taken under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: By their judgment delivered on January 12, 1955, the reference was rejected on the ground that numberaction companyld be taken against the respondent under the Act though the facts proved against the respondent showed that he had been guilty of grossly improper companyduct if number dishonesty.

facts.text: The Supreme Court held that the respondent's conduct as liquidator amounts to professional misconduct.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that, on the facts proved, the respondent is clearly guilty of professional misconduct.

facts.text: The respondent was appointed liquidator by the Calcutta High Court presumably because he was a chartered accountant in practice.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was appointed a liquidator by the Calcutta High Court presumably because he was a chartered accountant in practice.

issues.text: what is the nature, scope and extent of the disciplinary jurisdiction which can be exercised under the provisions of this Act against the respondent

anchor.surface_text: On these facts the main point which arises for our decision is what is the nature, scope and extent of the disciplinary jurisdiction which can be exercised under the provisions of this Act against the respondent.

whether on the facts proved disciplinary jurisdiction can be invoked against the respondent under the provisions of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The only point in dispute between the parties has been whether on the facts proved disciplinary jurisdiction can be invoked against the respondent under the provisions of the Act.

arguments.claim: The respondent's conduct cannot be said to be professional misconduct properly so-called and therefore cannot attract provisions of ss. 21 and 22

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the Calcutta High Court have held that the conduct of which the respondent is proved to have been guilty cannot be said to be professional misconduct properly so-called and cannot, therefore, attract the provisions of ss. 21 and 22 of the Act.

arguments.claim: Respondent's conduct as liquidator amounts to professional misconduct as deemed in practice under s.2(2)(iv)

anchor.surface_text: Let us first consider whether the conduct of the respondent amounts to professional misconduct or not. In dealing with this question it is necessary to bear in mind the provisions of s. 2, sub-s. (2)(iv) of the Act. A member of the Institute under this provision shall be deemed to be in practice when he renders such other services as in the opinion of the Council are or may be rendered by a chartered accountant.

arguments.claim: Regulation 78 confirms liquidator services deemed in practice under s.2(2)(iv)

anchor.surface_text: Regulation 78 is one of the regulations originally framed by the Central Government under s. 30, sub-s. (4) It reads thus Regulation 78. Without prejudice to the discretion vested in the Council in this behalf, a Chartered Accountant may act as liquidator, trustee, executor, administrator, arbitrator, receiver,

arguments.claim: s.22 provides inclusive definition of misconduct; does not limit s.21 powers to inquire into other unfit conduct

anchor.surface_text: Section 22 purports to define the expression conduct which, if proved, will render a person unfit to be a member of the Institute. It is an inclusive definition it includes any act or omission specified in the schedule but the latter portion of s. 22 clearly lays down that nothing contained in this section shall be construed to limit or abridge in any way the power conferred on the Council under sub-s. (1) of section 21

arguments.claim: ss.8(v)(vi) support disciplinary jurisdiction beyond schedule acts

anchor.surface_text: In this connection it would be relevant to mention s. 8 which deals with disabilities. Section 8, sub-ss. (v) and (vi), support the argument that disciplinary jurisdiction can be exercised against chartered accountants even in respect of conduct which may not fall expressly within the inclusive definition contained in s. 22.

Conduct as witness not professional misconduct (G.M. Oka precedent)

holdings.text: the respondent is clearly guilty of professional misconduct

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that, on the facts proved, the respondent is clearly guilty of professional misconduct. This would really dispose of the appeal before us, because once it is held that the respondent is guilty of professional misconduct it would be obviously necessary to deal with him on that basis and make an appropriate order under s. 21, sub-s.  3  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Respondent acting as liquidator deemed 'in practice' under s.2(2)(iv) read with Regulation 78; failures to report progress, honour cheque, hand over assets/records constitute professional misconduct.

holdings.text: when the respondent was working as a liquidator in pursuance of an order passed by the Calcutta High Court he must be deemed to be in practice within the meaning of s. 2, sub-s. 2

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of Regulation 78 must inevitably be considered in the light of s. 2, sub-s. 2 , cl.  iv  and the result of considering the two provisions together obviously is that when the respondent was working as a liquidator in pursuance of an order passed by the Calcutta High Court he must be deemed to be in practice within the meaning of s. 2, sub-s. 2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Regulation 78 authorizes chartered accountants to act as liquidators; s.2(2)(iv) deems rendering such services as 'in practice'; extends disciplinary jurisdiction to liquidator conduct.

holdings.text: the list of the said acts and omissions is not exhaustive and, in any event, the said list does not purport to limit the powers of the Council under s. 21, sub-s. (1)

anchor.surface_text: The position thus appears to be that though the definition of the Material expression used in s. 21, sub-s.  1 , refers to the acts and omissions specified in the schedule, the list of the said acts and omissions is not exhaustiveand, in any event, the said list does not purport to limit the powers of the Council under s. 21, sub-s.  1 , which may otherwise flow from the words used in the said sub-s. itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.22 is inclusive definition ('deemed to include'); expressly preserves Council's s.21(1) powers to inquire into any conduct rendering unfit, beyond Schedule.

holdings.text: if a member of the Institute is found, prima facie, guilty of conduct which, in the opinion of the Council, renders him unfit to be a member of the Institute, even though such conduct may not attract any of the provisions of the schedule, it would still be open to the Council to hold an inquiry against the member
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.22 latter portion saves s.21(1) powers; ss.8(v),(vi) support broad jurisdiction over unfit conduct beyond Schedule.

holdings.text: in confining the exercise of disciplinary jurisdiction only to cases of professional misconduct, technically so-called, the learned Judges of the Calcutta High Court have misconstrued the relevant provisions of the Act

anchor.surface_text: However, since the learned Attorney-General has alternatively urged before us that in confining the exercise of disciplinary jurisdiction only to cases of professional misconduct, technically so-called, the learned Judges of the Calcutta High Court have misconstrued the relevant provisions of the Act, we propose to deal very briefly with that question also.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erroneously limited to narrow 'professional misconduct'; ignored s.2(2)(iv) extension and inclusive s.22 not limiting s.21.

holdings.text: we must reverse the conclusion of the learned Judges of the Calcutta High Court that the conduct proved against the respondent does not fall within ss. 21 and 22
holdings.reasoning_summary: Conduct as liquidator is professional under extended definition; s.22 inclusive preserves broad jurisdiction.

holdings.text: The powers of the High Court under s. 21, sub-s. 3, are undoubtedly wide enough to enable the High Court to adopt any course which in its opinion will enable the High Court to do complete justice between the parties
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.21(2) requires hearing; s.21(3) allows final orders or refer back; can examine findings, direct alternative findings on undisputed facts.

holdings.text: the learned Judges of the High Court were in error in holding that, even if they had accepted the broader interpretation of s. 21 and s. 22, they could not make an appropriate order in the present case against the respondent having regard to the specific finding recorded by the Council
holdings.reasoning_summary: Wide powers not bound by Council's phrasing; facts undisputed, can pass final orders or vary.

holdings.text: The conduct of the respondent is, in our opinion, wholly unworthy of a chartered accountant in practice ... it calls for a deterrent order
holdings.reasoning_summary: Inference from undisputed facts: delaying tactics due to inability to return assets; grossly improper warranting deterrence.

precedents.citation: G. M. Oka, In re 1952 22 Comp. Cas. 168

anchor.surface_text: In G. M. Oka, In re 1 , it has been held by a Division Bench of the Bombay High Court that, when a chartered accountant gives evidence before a companyrt of law and he is in the witness box number as a chartered 1 1952 22 Comp. Cas. 168.

precedents.cited_proposition: when a chartered accountant gives evidence before a court of law and he is in the witness box not as a chartered accountant but as a witness, the falsity of his statement does not give rise to any disciplinary proceedings against him as a chartered accountant; conviction for perjury may call for disciplinary action

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Ashwini Kumar Ghosh, for the respondent, has also sought to rely on Haseldine v. Hosken 1 . In this case the solicitor had taken out an indemnity policy which insured him against loss arising by reason of any neglect, omission or error while acting in his. professional capacity. 1 1933 1 K.B. 822.

precedents.cited_proposition: loss sustained by solicitor through entering champertous agreement did not arise by reason of neglect, omission or error in professional capacity but from personal speculation

precedents.citation: Krishnaswamy v. The Council of the Institute of Chartered Accountants 1

anchor.surface_text: Similarly the decision in Krishnaswamy v. The Council of the Institute of Chartered Accountants 1 where the court was primarily concerned with the question as to whether orders passed under s. 21 2 of the Act are orders passed in civil proceedings or not is wholly inapplicable

precedents.case_name: Krishnaswamy v. The Council of the Institute of Chartered Accountants
precedents.cited_proposition: whether orders passed under s. 21(2) of the Act are orders passed in civil proceedings

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that, on the facts proved, the respondent is clearly guilty of professional misconduct. This would really dispose of the appeal before us, because once it is held that the respondent is guilty of professional misconduct it would be obviously necessary to deal with him on that basis and make an appropriate order under s. 21, sub-s. 3 of the Act.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal disposed of by holding respondent guilty of professional misconduct; requires making appropriate order under s.21(3); conduct found grossly improper warranting deterrent order

Pass deterrent order as conduct is grossly improper and unworthy

Regulation 78 authorizes chartered accountants to act as liquidators and links to S.2(2)(iv) deeming them 'in practice', which grounds the holding that the respondent as court-appointed liquidator is deemed in practice under s.2(2).

The inclusive definition in S.22 that does not limit S.21 powers grounds the holding rejecting the narrow confinement of disciplinary jurisdiction to professional misconduct technically so-called as a misconstrual.
The inclusive definition addresses the issue of the Calcutta High Court's misconstrual by confining disciplinary jurisdiction only to cases of professional misconduct technically so-called.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of Regulation 78 must inevitably be considered in the light of s. 2, sub-s. 2 , cl.  iv  and the result of considering the two provisions together obviously is that when the respondent was working as a liquidator in pursuance of an order passed by the Calcutta High Court he must be deemed to be in practice within the meaning of s. 2, sub-s. 2 .

We must, therefore, hold that, on the facts proved, the respondent is clearly guilty of professional misconduct. This would really dispose of the appeal before us, because once it is held that the respondent is guilty of professional misconduct it would be obviously necessary to deal with him on that basis and make an appropriate order under s. 21, sub-s. 3 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The position thus appears to be that though the definition of the Material expression used in s. 21, sub-s.  1 , refers to the acts and omissions specified in the schedule, the list of the said acts and omissions is not exhaustiveand, in any event, the said list does not purport to limit the powers of the Council under s. 21, sub-s.  1 , which may otherwise flow from the words used in the said sub-s. itself.

We must, therefore, hold that, on the facts proved, the respondent is clearly guilty of professional misconduct. This would really dispose of the appeal before us, because once it is held that the respondent is guilty of professional misconduct it would be obviously necessary to deal with him on that basis and make an appropriate order under s. 21, sub-s. 3 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: However, since the learned Attorney-General has alternatively urged before us that in confining the exercise of disciplinary jurisdiction only to cases of professional misconduct, technically so-called, the learned Judges of the Calcutta High Court have misconstrued the relevant provisions of the Act, we propose to deal very briefly with that question also.

We must, therefore, hold that, on the facts proved, the respondent is clearly guilty of professional misconduct. This would really dispose of the appeal before us, because once it is held that the respondent is guilty of professional misconduct it would be obviously necessary to deal with him on that basis and make an appropriate order under s. 21, sub-s. 3 of the Act.
